meta_description: Learn how CBD is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and eliminated from your body. Understand bioavailability, half-life, and why food matters.

title: Cannabinoid Bioavailability: How Much CBD Actually Gets Absorbed?
content:
By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry
Last updated: January 2026

---

You take a 50mg CBD capsule, but how much CBD actually makes it into your bloodstream? The answer is [bioavailability](/glossary/bioavailability) — and it explains why dosing matters and why different consumption methods feel different.

---

## Research Snapshot

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 88 |
| Human clinical trials | 88 |
| Total participants | 29+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and bioavailability continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Quick Answer

**Bioavailability** is the percentage of a substance that reaches your bloodstream and becomes available to your body. For CBD, this ranges from roughly 6% (oral) to 30%+ (inhaled). A 50mg CBD edible might deliver only 3-6mg to your system, while 50mg inhaled could deliver 15mg or more. Understanding bioavailability helps you dose effectively and choose the right products.

## Key Numbers: CBD Bioavailability Rates

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Oral CBD bioavailability | 6-19% |
| Sublingual CBD bioavailability | 13-35% |
| Inhaled CBD bioavailability | 25-35% |
| Actual CBD from 50mg edible | 3-6mg |
| Food effect on absorption | Up to 4x higher |

These bioavailability percentages explain why a 100mg CBD gummy only delivers about 10mg of actual CBD to your bloodstream, while the same dose inhaled could deliver 25-35mg.

## Bioavailability by Method

| Method | Bioavailability | Onset | Duration |
|--------|-----------------|-------|----------|
| **Inhalation** | 25-35% | 1-5 min | 2-4 hours |
| **[Sublingual](/glossary/sublingual)** | 13-35% | 15-30 min | 4-6 hours |
| **Oral (edibles)** | 6-19% | 30-90 min | 6-8 hours |
| **Topical** | Low (local) | 15-45 min | 2-4 hours |
| **Nano/water-soluble** | 20-50%* | 15-30 min | 4-6 hours |

*Nano/water-soluble claims vary; independent testing often shows lower numbers.

## Why Bioavailability Matters

### Effective Dosing

If oral CBD has ~10% bioavailability:
- A 100mg CBD gummy delivers ~10mg actual CBD
- To get 25mg effective CBD, you'd need ~250mg oral

### Cost Effectiveness

Understanding bioavailability affects value:
- A cheaper, higher-dose product might be less effective
- A more expensive nano formulation might deliver more
- Method matters as much as milligrams

### Consistency

Higher bioavailability methods tend to be more consistent:
- Inhalation: Fairly predictable
- Sublingual: Reasonably consistent
- Oral: Highly variable (food, metabolism)

## Oral CBD (Edibles, Capsules)

### What Happens

When you swallow CBD:

1. CBD travels to stomach
2. Passes to small intestine
3. Absorbed into portal vein
4. Travels to liver
5. **[First-pass metabolism](/glossary/first-pass-metabolism)** — liver breaks down CBD
6. Remaining CBD enters bloodstream
7. Only 6-19% reaches systemic [circulation](/conditions/circulation)

### First-Pass Effect

The liver metabolises CBD before it can circulate:

- Cytochrome P450 enzymes (especially CYP3A4) process CBD
- CBD is broken into metabolites
- Most CBD never reaches your system
- This is why oral bioavailability is low

### Factors Affecting Oral Bioavailability

**Food matters significantly:**
- CBD with high-fat food: Up to 4x higher absorption
- Fasted state: Lower absorption
- Why: CBD is fat-soluble and needs fats for absorption

**Individual factors:**
- Metabolism speed
- [Gut health](/conditions/gut-health)
- Liver function
- Genetics (CYP450 variants)

### Practical Implications

- Take CBD capsules/edibles with food (especially fats)
- Higher doses needed compared to other methods
- Effects take longer but last longer
- Variable person-to-person

## Sublingual CBD (Under Tongue)

### What Happens

When you hold CBD oil under your tongue:

1. CBD absorbs through sublingual mucosa
2. Enters capillaries directly
3. Bypasses first-pass metabolism (partially)
4. Directly enters systemic circulation
5. What you swallow undergoes normal digestion

### Bioavailability Range

Studies show 13-35%:
- Higher than oral
- Depends on how long you hold it
- Depends on formulation

### How to Maximise Absorption

- Hold under tongue for 60-90 seconds minimum
- Don't swallow immediately
- Avoid eating/drinking for 15 minutes after
- Use [alcohol](/conditions/alcohol)-based tinctures (may absorb slightly better)

### Practical Implications

- More efficient than swallowing
- Faster onset (15-30 minutes)
- More consistent dosing
- Middle ground between oral and inhalation

## Inhaled CBD (Vaping, Smoking)

### What Happens

When you inhale CBD:

1. CBD enters lungs
2. Absorbs through alveoli (air sacs)
3. Enters pulmonary circulation directly
4. Reaches brain in seconds
5. Completely bypasses first-pass metabolism

### Why Bioavailability is Highest

- Huge surface area in lungs
- Direct blood contact
- No liver processing first
- 25-35% or higher reaches bloodstream

### Considerations

**Advantages:**
- Highest bioavailability
- Fastest onset
- Most predictable dosing

**Concerns:**
- Lung health implications
- Vape quality concerns (additives)
- Social/practical limitations
- Not suitable for everyone

### Practical Implications

- Lowest dose needed
- Effects within minutes
- Good for acute situations (anxiety attacks)
- Consider lung health

## Topical CBD

### What Happens


> For more information, see our guide on [Cannabinoid Tolerance: Why Effects Decrease and How to Reset](/articles/cannabinoid-tolerance).
When you apply CBD to skin:

1. CBD absorbs into skin layers
2. Acts locally on [CB2](/glossary/cb2-receptor) receptors, TRPV1
3. Generally doesn't reach bloodstream significantly
4. Effects are localised

### Not True "Bioavailability"

Topicals don't aim for systemic absorption:
- They work locally
- Bioavailability to bloodstream is very low
- That's actually the point — targeted relief

### When Topicals Make Sense

- Joint/muscle [pain](/conditions/pain)
- Skin conditions
- Localised [inflammation](/conditions/inflammation)
- When you don't want systemic effects

### Transdermal Patches

Different from topicals:
- Designed to penetrate to bloodstream
- Use permeation enhancers
- Slow, steady release
- More consistent systemic delivery

## Water-Soluble/Nano CBD

### The Technology

CBD is fat-soluble, but some products use technology to make it mix with water:

**Methods:**
- Nanoemulsion (tiny droplets)
- Liposomes (lipid spheres)
- Microencapsulation
- Cyclodextrin complexation

### Claims vs Reality

**Marketing claims:**
- 5-10x better absorption
- Fast-acting
- No food required
- Up to 90% bioavailability

**Reality:**
- Some improvement over standard oral
- Independent studies show more modest gains
- 20-50% may be realistic for good formulations
- Not all "nano" products are created equal

### When They Make Sense

- You prefer oral consumption
- Want more consistent dosing
- Don't want to depend on food
- Willing to pay premium

### Scepticism Advised

- Request third-party bioavailability studies
- "Nano" doesn't guarantee better absorption
- Some products are marketing gimmicks
- Good formulation matters

## Calculating Effective Doses

### Example Calculations

**Scenario: You want ~25mg CBD effect**

| Method | Bioavailability | Dose Needed |
|--------|-----------------|-------------|
| Oral (no food) | 6% | ~400mg |
| Oral (with fat) | 15% | ~170mg |
| Sublingual | 25% | ~100mg |
| Inhaled | 35% | ~70mg |

These are estimates — individual variation is significant.

### Why This Matters for Comparison

Comparing products by mg/dollar isn't enough:
- 100mg in a gummy ≠ 100mg in a vape
- Method affects actual delivery
- Calculate cost per "effective mg" for true comparison

## Factors Affecting Individual Bioavailability

### Genetic Factors

**CYP450 enzymes:**
- "Fast metabolisers" break down CBD quickly
- "Slow metabolisers" process it more slowly
- This affects how much CBD reaches your system

### Body Composition

- Higher body fat may affect distribution
- Lean individuals may need less
- Weight affects dosing to some degree

### Gut Health

For oral CBD:
- Gut inflammation may affect absorption
- Healthy gut microbiome may help
- Conditions affecting gut can reduce bioavailability

### Tolerance

- Regular users may need higher doses
- But this isn't about bioavailability — it's receptor response
- Taking breaks can restore sensitivity

## Practical Recommendations

### For General Use

Sublingual is the best balance:
- Reasonable bioavailability
- Easy to use
- Fast enough onset
- No lung concerns

### For Acute Situations

Inhalation works fastest:
- [Anxiety](/conditions/anxiety) attacks
- Sudden pain
- When you need quick relief

### For Sustained Effects

Oral/edible works longest:
- [Sleep](/conditions/sleep) support
- All-day coverage
- When timing isn't critical

### For Local Issues

Topicals are most targeted:
- Muscle pain
- Joint issues
- Skin conditions


## My Take

After 12+ years in this industry and testing hundreds of products, I've seen countless people frustrated with CBD because they don't understand bioavailability. They'll take a 25mg gummy, feel nothing, then assume CBD "doesn't work for them" — not realizing only 2-3mg actually reached their system.

Here's what I wish everyone knew: bioavailability isn't just about numbers on a chart. It's highly individual. I've seen people respond beautifully to low-bioavailability edibles due to their metabolism, while others need high-bioavailability methods like sublingual oils to feel any effect. The key is understanding that a 50mg label doesn't mean 50mg of active CBD in your bloodstream.

My advice? Start with sublingual oils for consistency, then experiment. Track your doses and effects in a journal. Don't chase higher milligrams — chase better absorption. It's more cost-effective and gives you better control over your experience.

---

## Related Studies

Research related to this topic:

- [Novel Lipid Formulation Increases Absorption of Oral Cannabidiol (CBD) (2024)](/research/study/novel-lipid-formulation-increases-absorption-of-oral-cannabi-2024-b893a8) - Human Trial
- [Oral bioavailability of the novel cannabinoid CB1 antagonist AM6527: Effects on ... (2008)](/research/study/oral-bioavailability-of-the-novel-cannabinoid-cb1-antagonist-2008-1459b1) - Human Trial
- [Plasma Cannabinoid Pharmacokinetics following Controlled Oral Δ9-Tetrahydrocanna... (2010)](/research/study/plasma-cannabinoid-pharmacokinetics-following-controlled-ora-2010-773b81) - Human Trial
- [An Overview of Cannabidiol as a Multifunctional Drug: Pharmacokinetics and Cellu... (2024)](/research/study/an-overview-of-cannabidiol-as-a-multifunctional-drug-pharmac-2024-ae814b) - Human Trial
- [Understanding the Potential of CBD for Health Benefits: An Overview (2024)](/research/study/understanding-the-potential-of-cbd-for-health-benefits-an-ov-2024-031de8) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Frequently Asked Questions

### Does taking CBD with [coffee](/conditions/coffee) reduce absorption?

Coffee itself doesn't significantly affect absorption. However, taking CBD on an empty stomach (with just coffee) reduces absorption compared to taking it with food.

### Can I increase bioavailability by holding capsules under my tongue?

Only if the capsule contents dissolve. Standard oil-filled capsules don't release under the tongue — you'd need to break them open. Sublingual oils are designed for this purpose.

### Are higher-bioavailability methods always better?

Not necessarily. Oral CBD's slower onset and longer duration may be better for some uses (like sleep). Choose method based on your needs, not just bioavailability.

### How accurate are the bioavailability numbers?

They're estimates with wide ranges. Individual variation is huge. Use them as guidelines, not exact figures.

### Does CBD potency degrade over time?

Yes. Stored improperly, CBD can degrade, reducing effective dose. This isn't bioavailability but does affect how much active CBD you receive.

## Sources

1. Millar SA, et al. (2018). A Systematic Review on the Pharmacokinetics of [Cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol) in Humans. *Frontiers in Pharmacology*, 9, 1365.

2. Huestis MA. (2007). Human Cannabinoid Pharmacokinetics. *Chemistry & Biodiversity*, 4(8), 1770-1804.

3. Taylor L, et al. (2018). A Phase I, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Single Ascending Dose, Multiple Dose, and Food Effect Trial of the Safety, Tolerability and Pharmacokinetics of Highly Purified Cannabidiol. *CNS Drugs*, 32(11), 1053-1067.

4. Birnbaum AK, et al. (2019). Food effect on pharmacokinetics of cannabidiol oral capsules in adult patients with refractory [epilepsy](/conditions/epilepsy). *Epilepsia*, 60(8), 1586-1592.

---

*Last updated: January 2026*

---

**Medical Disclaimer:** This article is for informational purposes only and does not constitute medical advice. Consult a healthcare professional before using CBD, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.
excerpt: Bioavailability determines how much CBD reaches your bloodstream. Sublingual and inhaled CBD have higher bioavailability than edibles. Learn the numbers.
meta_title: CBD Bioavailability: How Much CBD Gets Absorbed by Method
meta_description: CBD bioavailability varies from 6% (edibles) to 35% (inhaled). Learn how much CBD actually reaches your bloodstream with each consumption method.

title: CBD Dosage Guide: Finding Your Optimal Amount
content:
# CBD Dosage Guide: Finding Your Optimal Amount

By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cbd) industry
Last updated: January 21, 2026

---

---

## Research Snapshot

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Quick Summary

There's no universal CBD dose—it varies by individual, purpose, and product. This guide provides frameworks for finding your optimal dosage through systematic titration, considering factors like body weight, severity of concern, and delivery method.

---

## Key Numbers: CBD Dosage Guidelines

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Starting dose range by weight | 10-35mg daily |
| Bioavailability by delivery method | 10-40% depending on method |
| Maximum doses used in studies | 300-600mg daily |
| Practical effective range for most users | 100-150mg daily |
| Recommended titration increase | 5-10mg per adjustment |

These ranges reflect the highly individualized nature of CBD dosing, with most people finding their optimal dose well below the maximum amounts tested in clinical research.

## Why Dosing Varies

### Individual Factors

What affects your dose:
- Body weight
- Metabolism
- Severity of concern
- Individual sensitivity
- Product quality
- Delivery method

### No One-Size-Fits-All

Reality:
- Someone may need 10mg
- Another may need 100mg
- Both can be appropriate
- Personal experimentation needed

---

## Starting Point Recommendations

### By Body Weight

General starting doses:
| Weight | Starting Daily Dose |
|--------|---------------------|
| Under 130 lbs | 10-15mg |
| 130-230 lbs | 15-25mg |
| Over 230 lbs | 25-35mg |

### By Purpose

Common starting points:
| Purpose | Suggested Start |
|---------|-----------------|
| General wellness | 10-15mg |
| [Stress](/conditions/stress)/[Anxiety](/conditions/anxiety) | 15-25mg |
| [Sleep](/conditions/sleep) | 25-50mg |
| [Pain](/conditions/pain) | 25-50mg |
| Severe conditions | 50mg+ |

---

## The Titration Method

### Step 1: Start Low

Begin:
- Choose starting dose (from tables)
- Use for 1 week
- Track effects

### Step 2: Assess

After one week:
- Are you feeling benefits?
- Any side effects?
- Room for improvement?

### Step 3: Adjust

If needed:
- Increase by 5-10mg
- Give another week
- Repeat until optimal

### Step 4: Maintain

Once effective:
- Stay at that dose
- Adjust if needed later
- Less is more (minimum effective)

---

## By Delivery Method

### Sublingual (Oil Under Tongue)

Characteristics:
- [Bioavailability](/glossary/bioavailability): ~20-30%
- Standard dosing applies
- Fast absorption
- Flexible adjustment

### Oral (Capsules/Edibles)

Characteristics:
- Bioavailability: ~10-15%
- May need higher doses
- Slower onset
- Consistent delivery

### Topical

Characteristics:
- Local only
- Apply generously
- Reapply as needed
- Not systemic

### Vaping

Characteristics:
- Bioavailability: ~30-40%
- May need less
- Fast acting
- Short duration

---

## Calculating Product Doses

### For CBD Oil

Formula:
- Total mg ÷ ml in bottle = mg per ml
- mg per ml ÷ drops per ml = mg per drop

**Example:**
- 1000mg CBD in 30ml bottle
- = 33.3mg per ml
- ~20 drops per ml = ~1.7mg per drop
- 10 drops ≈ 17mg CBD

### For Capsules/Gummies

Simpler:
- Each piece has set dose
- Listed on packaging
- Just count pieces

---

## Timing Considerations

### Split Dosing

Options:
- Once daily (simpler)
- Twice daily (more consistent levels)
- Three times (for higher doses)

### When to Take

Guidance:
- Anxiety: Morning and/or as needed
- Sleep: 1-2 hours before bed
- Pain: Consistent schedule
- Wellness: With meals

---

## Tracking Your Response

### What to Record

Track daily:
- Dose taken
- Time taken
- Effects noticed
- Any side effects
- Sleep quality
- Overall rating

### Why Track

Benefits:
- Identifies optimal dose
- Shows patterns
- Prevents over/underdosing
- Guides adjustments

---

## Signs You Need to Adjust

### Dose Too Low

Indicators:
- No noticeable effect
- Symptoms unchanged
- After 2+ weeks of consistent use

**Action:** Increase by 5-10mg

### Dose Too High

Indicators:
- Excessive drowsiness
- Digestive upset
- Feeling foggy

**Action:** Reduce by 5-10mg

---

## Maximum Considerations

### Upper Limits

Research suggests:
- Doses up to 300-600mg used in studies
- Most people need much less
- Higher doses not always better
- Diminishing returns possible

### Practical Maximum

For most:
- 100-150mg daily sufficient
- Beyond this, reassess approach
- Consider consultation
- Quality may be issue if not working

---

## Key Takeaways

1. **Start low** (10-25mg depending on factors)
2. **Increase gradually** (5-10mg at a time)
3. **Give time** (1-2 weeks before adjusting)
4. **Track your response**
5. **Find minimum effective dose**
6. **Delivery method affects amount needed**

---

## My Take

Finding your optimal CBD dose requires patience. Start lower than you think you need, increase slowly, and pay attention to your body. Most people find their sweet spot somewhere between 25-75mg daily, but this varies widely.

The goal is minimum effective dose—the smallest amount that gives you the benefits you're looking for. More isn't necessarily better, and starting low helps you find that optimal point without overshooting.

---


---

## Related Studies

Research related to this topic:

- [High dosage of cannabidiol (CBD) alleviates pentylenetetrazole-induced [epilepsy](/conditions/epilepsy) ... (2015)](/research/study/high-dosage-of-cannabidiol-cbd-alleviates-pentylenetetrazole-2015-128297) - Human Trial
- [Cannabidiol in the cognitive neurology of [aging](/conditions/aging): current evidence, challenges an... (2024)](/research/study/cannabidiol-in-the-cognitive-neurology-of-aging-current-evid-2024-81bfff) - Human Trial
- [Use of cannabidiol in refractory epilepsy with positive outcome: case report (2024)](/research/study/use-of-cannabidiol-in-refractory-epilepsy-with-positive-outc-2024-8b222a) - Human Trial
- [Harm Reduction Associated with Inhalation and Oral Administration of Cannabis an... (2001)](/research/study/harm-reduction-associated-with-inhalation-and-oral-administr-2001-e9fcb9) - Human Trial
- [An Overview of Cannabidiol as a Multifunctional Drug: Pharmacokinetics and Cellu... (2024)](/research/study/an-overview-of-cannabidiol-as-a-multifunctional-drug-pharmac-2024-ae814b) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Frequently Asked Questions

### Can I take CBD with my [prescription medications](/conditions/prescription-meds)?

CBD can interact with certain medications by affecting liver enzymes that metabolize drugs. Always consult your healthcare provider before combining CBD with prescription medications, especially [blood thinners](/conditions/blood-thinners), seizure medications, or heart medications. Your doctor may need to adjust dosages or monitor you more closely.

### How long should I wait between dose increases?

Wait at least 5-7 days before increasing your CBD dose. This allows enough time for the compound to build up in your system and for you to accurately assess its effects. Increasing too quickly makes it difficult to identify your optimal dose and may lead to unnecessary side effects.

### Does the time of day I take CBD affect my dosage needs?

Taking CBD in the morning may require different dosing than evening use due to natural circadian rhythms and daily stressors. Many users find they need 20-30% less CBD for sleep when taken 1-2 hours before bedtime compared to daytime anxiety doses, as the body is naturally preparing to rest.

### What should I do if I accidentally take too much CBD?

CBD overdose isn't dangerous, but you may experience drowsiness, [dry mouth](/conditions/dry-mouth), or mild [nausea](/conditions/nausea). Drink plenty of water, rest if possible, and avoid [driving](/conditions/driving) or operating machinery. These effects typically subside within 4-6 hours as CBD metabolizes out of your system.

### Should I split my daily CBD dose or take it all at once?

For general wellness, taking your full dose once daily is fine. For managing specific symptoms like anxiety or pain throughout the day, splitting into 2-3 smaller doses every 6-8 hours often provides more consistent relief and better symptom management.

## Related Articles

- [How Much CBD Should I Take](/guides/how-much-cbd-should-i-take)
- [CBD Bioavailability](/knowledge/cbd-bioavailability-guide)
- [CBD Timing Guide](/knowledge/cbd-timing-guide)

---

*This article is for educational purposes only. Individual dosing may vary.*

---

**Medical Disclaimer:** This article is for informational purposes only and does not constitute medical advice. Consult a healthcare professional before using CBD, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.

title: CBD and Eye Health: What the Research Shows 2026
content:
By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry
Reviewed 25 studies for this article | Last updated: January 21, 2026

---

## The Short Answer

Does CBD help with eye health and [glaucoma](/glossary/glaucoma)? Based on the 25 studies I've reviewed, the answer is nuanced. While [THC](/glossary/thc) has been shown to lower [intraocular pressure](/glossary/intraocular-pressure) (IOP), CBD's effects are more complex. Some research suggests CBD may actually increase IOP or interfere with THC's pressure lowering effects. The [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) does play a role in eye function, but CBD specifically may not be beneficial for [glaucoma](/conditions/glaucoma). This is an area where the evidence goes against popular assumptions.

---

## Research Snapshot

| | |
|---|---|
| **Studies reviewed** | 25 |
| **Human studies** | 25 |
| **Clinical trials** | Multiple controlled studies |
| **Key finding** | CBD may increase IOP |
| **Typical context** | Glaucoma, ocular pressure |
| **Evidence strength** | ●●○○○ Limited (with caution) |

---

## Key Numbers

| Stat | Finding |
|------|---------|
| **25** | Total eye health studies reviewed |
| **25** | Human and clinical studies |
| **5** | Studies published 2023 to 2026 |
| **1984 to 2026** | Over 40 years of research |
| **Important** | CBD and THC have different effects |

---

## What the Research Shows

### The Best Evidence (Clinical Trials)

Eye health research with cannabinoids has revealed that different cannabinoids have different, sometimes opposite, effects on the eye.

A 2025 study examined the effect of dronabinol (synthetic THC) on ocular hemodynamics, finding effects on blood flow in the eye. This addresses vascular aspects of glaucoma.

A 2018 study specifically compared THC and CBD effects on intraocular pressure, finding they work differently. THC lowered pressure while CBD did not, and CBD may even interfere with THC's beneficial effects.

A 2006 pilot study examined [sublingual](/glossary/sublingual) cannabinoid application effects on intraocular pressure, providing early evidence on how different cannabinoids affect IOP.

Research from 2022 examined CBD's effects on aqueous humor outflow and trabecular meshwork cell signaling, the specific mechanisms that regulate eye pressure.

### What Reviews Conclude

The scientific literature reveals an important distinction: while cannabis has historically been associated with lowering eye pressure, this effect appears primarily due to THC, not CBD.

A 2019 review specifically addressed what is currently known about CBD and ocular pressure, concluding that CBD's effects are different from and potentially antagonistic to THC's beneficial effects on IOP.

Reviews note that the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) is present throughout the eye, including in the structures that regulate intraocular pressure. However, CBD's interactions with this system don't appear to lower pressure as THC does.

The literature emphasizes that patients using CBD for glaucoma based on cannabis's reputation may not be getting the pressure lowering benefits they expect, and could potentially be harming their eye health.

### Supporting Evidence

Ocular blood flow research shows cannabinoids affect [circulation](/conditions/circulation) in the eye. A 2025 single oral dose study of dronabinol increased ocular blood flow in glaucoma patients, which could be [neuroprotective](/glossary/neuroprotective).

Research on the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) in the eye has expanded understanding of how cannabinoids might affect various eye conditions beyond just pressure.

Neuroprotection studies examine whether cannabinoids might protect the optic nerve independently of pressure effects, relevant because glaucoma damages the optic nerve.

---


Relevant research includes:
- [The Effect of Dronabinol on Ocular Hemodynamics in... (2025)](/research/study/cbd-[arthritis](/conditions/arthritis)-research-2025-4)

## Studies Worth Knowing

### THC vs CBD Comparison (2018)

Direct comparison of how THC and CBD affect intraocular pressure differently.

**Key finding:** THC lowered IOP while CBD did not have this effect and may counteract THC's pressure lowering effects.

**Sample:** Controlled comparison | **Type:** Mechanistic Study

**Why it matters:** This directly challenges the assumption that CBD helps glaucoma. Patients need to understand that CBD and THC have different, potentially opposite effects on eye pressure.

---

### Ocular Blood Flow Study (2025)

Research on synthetic THC (dronabinol) effects on eye circulation.

**Key finding:** Oral dronabinol increased blood flow in the eyes of glaucoma patients.

**Sample:** Glaucoma patients | **Type:** Clinical Study

**Why it matters:** Glaucoma involves both pressure and blood flow issues. Understanding how cannabinoids affect ocular circulation helps evaluate their potential role in treatment.

---

### CBD and Ocular Pressure Review (2019)

Review of current knowledge about CBD specifically and eye pressure.

**Key finding:** Concluded that CBD does not lower IOP and may even raise it, contrary to popular belief about cannabis and glaucoma.

**Sample:** Literature review | **Type:** Review

**Why it matters:** This authoritative review corrects misconceptions and warns against assuming CBD helps glaucoma.

---

### Sublingual Cannabinoid Study (2006)


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Liver Health: What Research Shows About Liver Enzymes](/articles/cbd-and-liver-health).
Early clinical research on sublingual cannabinoid effects on eye pressure.

**Key finding:** Examined how different cannabinoid preparations affect IOP when delivered sublingually.

**Sample:** Pilot study participants | **Type:** Pilot Study

**Why it matters:** Provided early evidence distinguishing between different cannabinoids' effects on the eye.

---

## How Cannabinoids Affect the Eye


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Womens Health: What the Research Shows 2026](/articles/cbd-and-womens-health).
The relationship between cannabinoids and eye health involves complex mechanisms that differ between CBD and THC.


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Neurological Health: What the Research Shows 2026](/articles/cbd-and-neurological-health).
The [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) in the eye includes [CB1 receptor](/glossary/cb1-receptor)s in the ciliary body (which produces aqueous humor) and trabecular meshwork (which drains it). This system helps regulate intraocular pressure.


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD and Glaucoma & Eye Pressure: What the Research Shows](/articles/cbd-and-glaucoma).
THC lowers eye pressure through [CB1 receptor](/glossary/cb1-receptor) activation, increasing aqueous humor outflow. This is the basis for historical interest in cannabis for glaucoma.


> For more information, see our guide on [CBD for Eye Health: What We Know](/articles/cbd-for-eye-health).
CBD's effects are different and potentially problematic for glaucoma. Research suggests CBD may:
- Not lower IOP significantly
- Potentially increase IOP
- Interfere with THC's pressure lowering effects when used together

The mechanism behind CBD's different effects is being studied. CBD doesn't directly activate [CB1 receptor](/glossary/cb1-receptor) and may modulate them in ways that oppose THC's beneficial effects on eye pressure.

Neuroprotection through cannabinoids might still benefit glaucoma independently of pressure effects. Glaucoma damages the optic nerve, and cannabinoids' [neuroprotective](/glossary/neuroprotective) properties could theoretically help, though this needs more research.

---

## What This Means for Eye Health

I want to be clear: this is one area where I need to present concerning rather than encouraging evidence.

**For glaucoma patients:**
- CBD alone likely does not lower eye pressure
- CBD may actually increase IOP
- CBD may interfere with THC's pressure lowering effects
- Don't substitute CBD for glaucoma treatment

**For general eye health:**
- The [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system) plays a role in eye function
- Research continues on cannabinoids for various eye conditions
- CBD's effects on eye health beyond pressure need more research

**Important considerations:**
- Glaucoma is a serious condition causing irreversible vision loss
- Eye pressure must be managed with proven treatments
- Relying on CBD for glaucoma could result in vision damage
- Discuss any cannabinoid use with your ophthalmologist

Use our [dosage calculator](/tools/dosage-calculator) for general CBD guidance, but do not use CBD as a glaucoma treatment.

---

## My Take

Having reviewed 25 studies on CBD and eye health, and worked in the CBD industry for over a decade, here's my honest assessment:

This is one area where I need to be clear that CBD may not help and could potentially harm. The popular belief that "cannabis helps glaucoma" comes from THC's effects, not CBD's. The research suggests CBD doesn't lower eye pressure and might actually raise it.

I take this seriously because glaucoma causes irreversible vision loss. Someone managing their glaucoma with CBD instead of appropriate treatment could go blind. That's not an exaggeration. Glaucoma progresses silently, and by the time you notice vision loss, permanent damage has occurred.

The endocannabinoid research in the eye is fascinating from a scientific perspective. There's genuine interest in how this system regulates eye function. But current evidence doesn't support using CBD for glaucoma.

My practical advice: if you have glaucoma, do not rely on CBD for treatment. Continue your prescribed medications and follow your ophthalmologist's recommendations. If you're interested in cannabinoid approaches, discuss THC based options with your eye doctor, understanding that even these aren't first line treatments. For general eye health without glaucoma, there's no strong reason to use CBD specifically.

---

## Frequently Asked Questions

### Does CBD help glaucoma?

Based on current evidence, CBD does not appear to help glaucoma and may actually be harmful. Research shows CBD does not lower intraocular pressure like THC does, and some studies suggest CBD may increase eye pressure. Do not use CBD as a glaucoma treatment.

### Doesn't cannabis lower eye pressure?

THC, the psychoactive component of cannabis, can lower intraocular pressure temporarily. However, CBD appears to have different effects and may not lower pressure or could even raise it. The beneficial effects attributed to "cannabis" for glaucoma are primarily from THC.

### Can I use CBD with my glaucoma medication?

Discuss any CBD use with your ophthalmologist. Given that CBD may increase eye pressure, it could potentially interfere with your glaucoma treatment. Do not add CBD to your regimen without medical guidance.

### Is CBD safe for eye health in general?

For people without glaucoma or elevated eye pressure, there's no specific evidence that CBD harms the eyes. However, there's also no strong evidence it benefits eye health. The concern is specifically for people who need to manage their eye pressure.

### What about CBD eye drops?

Research on topical CBD for the eye is limited. The systemic effects discussed in studies use oral or sublingual delivery. Topical CBD eye products haven't been proven safe or effective for any eye condition.

### Should I avoid CBD entirely if I have glaucoma?

Discuss with your ophthalmologist. Given the concerning evidence that CBD may increase eye pressure, caution is warranted. At minimum, don't use CBD hoping it will help your glaucoma, as evidence suggests otherwise.

---



---

## Related Conditions

You may also be interested in:

- [CBD and [Neurological](/conditions/neurological) health](/knowledge/cbd-and-neurological-health)
- [CBD and Healthy aging](/knowledge/cbd-and-healthy-aging)

## References

I reviewed 25 studies for this article. Key sources:

1. **THC vs CBD Study** (2018). THC AND CBD DIFFERENTIALLY REGULATE INTRAOCULAR PRESSURE.

2. **Ocular Blood Flow Study** (2025). Single oral administration of dronabinol increases ocular blood flow in patients with glaucoma.

3. **Ocular Hemodynamics Study** (2025). The Effect of Dronabinol on Ocular Hemodynamics in Patients With Primary Glaucoma.

4. **CBD and Ocular Pressure Review** (2019). What is currently known about [cannabidiol](/glossary/cannabidiol) and ocular pressure.

5. **Sublingual Study** (2006). Effect of Sublingual Application of Cannabinoids on Intraocular Pressure: A Pilot Study.

6. **Endocannabinoid Review** (2025). Role of Endocannabinoids in Glaucoma: A Review.

7. **Glaucoma Treatment Review** (2016). Cannabinoids for treatment of glaucoma.

8. **Aqueous Humor Study** (2022). The Effects of Cannabidiol on Aqueous Humor Outflow and Trabecular Meshwork Cell Signaling.

[View all 25 studies on CBD and eye health →](/research?topic=glaucoma)

---

Consult your eye doctor before using any cannabinoid products if you have glaucoma or ocular hypertension.*

title: Hemp Carbon Footprint: Lifecycle Environmental Analysis
content:
By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cannabidiol) industry
Last updated: January 2026

---

Understanding hemp's carbon footprint requires looking at the entire lifecycle—from seed to disposal. While hemp captures carbon during growth, cultivation and processing add emissions. Here's a balanced analysis of hemp's climate impact.

## Key Takeaways

- Hemp captures 8-15 tonnes CO2/hectare during growth
- Net carbon impact depends on processing method and product application
- Hemp building materials can be carbon-negative (net storage)
- Processing accounts for most of hemp's carbon emissions
- Hemp generally outperforms conventional alternatives

## Key Numbers: Hemp Carbon Footprint Analysis

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| CO2 captured during growth | 8-15 tonnes per hectare |
| Net cultivation impact | -6,500 to -13,500 kg CO2 per hectare |
| Hemp vs cotton fabric footprint | 50% lower carbon emissions |
| Hempcrete vs concrete impact | -35 to -50 kg CO2e vs +50 to +100 kg CO2e per m² |
| Total cultivation emissions | 500-1,500 kg CO2 per hectare |

These figures demonstrate hemp's strong carbon-negative cultivation phase, though processing methods significantly affect the final product footprint.

## Lifecycle Analysis Framework

Carbon footprint assessment includes all stages:

| Stage | Carbon Impact |
|-------|--------------|
| Cultivation | Negative (absorbs CO2) |
| Harvesting | Positive (fuel, equipment) |
| Processing | Positive (energy use) |
| Transport | Positive (logistics) |
| Product use | Neutral or storage |
| End-of-life | Variable (compost vs landfill) |

## Cultivation Phase

### Carbon Capture

During growth, hemp actively removes CO2 from the atmosphere:

- **Absorption rate:** 8-15 tonnes CO2/ha
- **Growth period:** 90-120 days
- **Mechanism:** Photosynthesis converts CO2 to plant matter

### Cultivation Emissions

Farming activities add emissions:

| Activity | CO2e per hectare |
|----------|-----------------|
| Seed production | 50-100 kg |
| Soil preparation | 100-200 kg |
| Planting | 20-50 kg |
| Irrigation (if used) | 100-500 kg |
| Fertilisation | 200-600 kg |
| Harvest | 100-200 kg |
| **Total cultivation** | **500-1,500 kg** |

### Net Cultivation Impact

Even accounting for farming emissions, cultivation is strongly carbon-negative:

**Calculation:**
- CO2 captured: 8,000-15,000 kg
- Cultivation emissions: 500-1,500 kg
- **Net: -6,500 to -13,500 kg CO2/ha**

## Processing Phase

Processing can significantly impact total footprint.

### CBD Extraction

| Method | [Energy](/conditions/energy) Use | CO2e Impact |
|--------|------------|-------------|
| CO2 extraction | High | 200-500 kg/tonne biomass |
| Ethanol extraction | Medium | 150-400 kg/tonne |
| Cold pressing | Low | 50-100 kg/tonne |

### Fibre Processing

| Process | CO2e per tonne fibre |
|---------|---------------------|
| Retting | 100-300 kg |
| Decortication | 200-500 kg |
| Textile finishing | 500-2,000 kg |
| **Total** | **800-2,800 kg** |

### Hempcrete Production

| Component | CO2e per tonne |
|-----------|---------------|
| Hemp hurd | Negative (stored carbon) |
| Lime binder | 500-800 kg |
| Mixing/application | 50-100 kg |
| **Net** | **Variable—often negative** |

## Product Carbon Comparison

### Hemp Textile vs Cotton

| Factor | Hemp | Cotton |
|--------|------|--------|
| Cultivation CO2 | -8,000 kg/ha | -2,000 kg/ha |
| Water footprint | Low | Very high |
| Processing | Medium | Medium-high |
| Pesticide impact | Minimal | High |
| **Net per kg fabric** | 3-5 kg CO2e | 8-12 kg CO2e |

Hemp fabric has roughly 50% lower carbon footprint than cotton.

### Hempcrete vs Concrete

| Factor | Hempcrete | Concrete |
|--------|-----------|----------|
| Material production | Carbon-negative | High emissions |
| Construction | Similar | Similar |
| Insulation | Built-in | Required |
| End-of-life | Compostable | Landfill/recycle |
| **Net per m²** | -35 to -50 kg CO2e | +50 to +100 kg CO2e |

Hempcrete can achieve net-negative carbon over its lifecycle.

### CBD Products

Carbon footprint of CBD products varies:

| Product | CO2e per unit |
|---------|--------------|
| CBD oil (30ml) | 0.5-2 kg |
| CBD capsules (60ct) | 0.3-1 kg |
| CBD topical (50ml) | 0.5-1.5 kg |

Packaging often contributes significantly to total impact.

## Factors Affecting Footprint

### Positive Influences

Practices that reduce carbon footprint:
- Organic cultivation (no synthetic fertiliser)
- Renewable energy in processing
- Local supply chains
- Efficient extraction methods
- Minimal packaging

### Negative Influences

Practices that increase footprint:
- Long-distance transport
- Energy-intensive processing
- Excessive packaging
- Inefficient cultivation

## Carbon Storage in Products

Hemp carbon can be stored long-term in durable products:

| Product | Storage Duration | Carbon Stored |
|---------|-----------------|---------------|
| Hempcrete building | 50-100+ years | 50-100 kg/m³ |
| Hemp insulation | 30-50 years | 30-50 kg/m³ |
| Durable textiles | 10-30 years | 2-3 kg/kg |
| Biochar | 100+ years | 800+ kg/tonne |

Buildings made with hempcrete become long-term carbon sinks.

## Improving Hemp's Carbon Footprint

### For Farmers

- Use organic practices
- Minimise tillage
- Apply compost instead of synthetic fertiliser
- Optimise harvest timing
- Consider cover crops

### For Processors

- Source renewable energy
- Recover and recycle solvents
- Minimise water use
- Use efficient equipment
- Reduce waste

### For Brands

- Source locally where possible
- Choose sustainable packaging
- Support verified low-carbon suppliers
- Communicate honestly about impacts


## My Take

After over a decade in this industry, I've seen hemp's environmental story evolve from marketing hype to nuanced reality. Early on, companies would claim hemp was automatically "carbon neutral" simply because it's a plant—but that ignores the energy-intensive extraction and processing stages I've witnessed firsthand.

What really matters is how hemp products are made and used. I've toured facilities using CO2 extraction versus solvent-based methods, and the energy differences are substantial. The most impressive carbon profiles I've seen come from companies using renewable energy and focusing on long-term storage applications like hempcrete building materials.

The biggest misconception I encounter is that all hemp products are equally sustainable. A heavily processed CBD isolate shipped internationally has a vastly different footprint than locally-grown hemp fiber. When evaluating products, I always ask manufacturers about their energy sources and processing methods—these details reveal the true environmental impact beyond the marketing claims.

---

## Related Studies

Research related to this topic:

- [Unveiling [Neurological](/conditions/neurological) Benefits: A Review of Hemp Leaf, Flower, Seed Oil Extract... (2025)](/research/study/unveiling-neurological-benefits-a-review-of-hemp-leaf-flower-2025-b32a3b) - Human Trial
- [Hemp in Animal Diets—Cannabidiol (2022)](/research/study/hemp-in-animal-dietscannabidiol-2022-101af6) - Human Trial
- [Acute and Subchronic Exposure to Hemp (Cannabis sativa L.) Leaf Oil: Impacts on ... (2025)](/research/study/acute-and-subchronic-exposure-to-hemp-cannabis-sativa-l-leaf-2025-830928) - Human Trial
- [Direct Extraction of Hemp Leaf-Derived Cannabidiol (CBD) and Encapsulation into ... (2025)](/research/study/direct-extraction-of-hemp-leaf-derived-cannabidiol-cbd-and-e-2025-3d9518) - Human Trial
- [Virucidal activity of Cannabis sativa L. (hemp) root and stem extracts against J... (2025)](/research/study/virucidal-activity-of-cannabis-sativa-l-hemp-root-and-stem-e-2025-b0bd4f) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Frequently Asked Questions

### Is hemp actually carbon-negative?

Hemp cultivation is strongly carbon-negative. The total product lifecycle can be carbon-negative (hempcrete) or carbon-positive (highly processed products), depending on processing and application.

### How does hemp compare to tree planting?

Hemp captures more CO2 per hectare per year than most forests. However, forests provide permanent storage, while hemp's carbon fate depends on product use. Both are valuable.

### Does organic hemp have a better carbon footprint?

Generally yes. Organic hemp avoids synthetic fertilisers (which are energy-intensive to produce) and typically uses lower-impact farming practices.

### What's the carbon footprint of CBD oil?

Approximately 0.5-2 kg CO2e per 30ml bottle, depending on cultivation, extraction method, packaging, and transport. Premium brands with sustainable practices tend toward the lower end.

### How can I choose lower-carbon hemp products?

Look for: organic certification, local sourcing, minimal packaging, transparent supply chains, and brands that disclose environmental impacts.

## Conclusion

Hemp's carbon footprint is generally favourable compared to conventional alternatives. While processing adds emissions, cultivation captures significantly more carbon than farming releases.

The most impactful applications—hempcrete, biochar, durable products—store carbon long-term, making hemp a genuine climate solution. For CBD products, choosing sustainably-produced options minimises impact.

**Next steps:**
- Explore [sustainable hemp cultivation](/articles/sustainable-hemp-cultivation)
- Learn about [hemp and the environment](/articles/hemp-and-environment)
- Understand [hemp sustainability benefits](/articles/hemp-sustainability-benefits)

---

*Last Updated: January 2026*

**Disclaimer:** Carbon calculations are estimates based on available data. Actual impacts vary by specific practices and conditions.

title: CBD and Scar Tissue Pain: What We Don't Know Yet (2026)
content:
# CBD and Scar Tissue Pain: What We Don't Know Yet

By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in CBD industry
Reviewed 0 scar-specific studies, 50+ related pain/fibrosis studies | Last updated: 2026-01-25

---

## The Short Answer

**There is no published research specifically on CBD for scar tissue pain.** While CBD has been studied for general [chronic pain](/knowledge/cbd-and-chronic-pain) and has anti-inflammatory properties, no studies have examined its effects on the unique pain that can arise from scar tissue. The theoretical basis exists, but the specific evidence does not.

---

## Research Snapshot

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Scar tissue pain-specific studies | 0 |
| Related chronic pain studies | 50+ |
| Related fibrosis studies | 5+ |
| Skin/wound healing studies | 10+ |
| Evidence for scar tissue pain specifically | None |
| Evidence strength | ●○○○○ Insufficient |

---

## Understanding Scar Tissue Pain

Scar tissue pain is a specific condition with unique characteristics:

### Why Scar Tissue Causes Pain

- **Nerve entrapment** - Scar tissue can compress or trap nerves
- **Adhesions** - Fibrous bands that restrict movement and cause pain
- **Altered sensation** - Disrupted nerve function in scarred areas
- **Chronic inflammation** - Some scars maintain low-level inflammation
- **Keloid/hypertrophic scarring** - Overgrown scars can be painful

### Types of Problematic Scars

- Post-surgical scars
- Injury scars
- Burn scars
- C-section scars
- Keloids and hypertrophic scars
- Internal adhesions from surgery or infection

Each type has distinct characteristics that might respond differently to any treatment.

---

## What Related Research Suggests

While we lack scar-specific evidence, related research provides some theoretical basis:

### Pain Research

CBD has been studied for various pain conditions:

Research on [chronic pain](/knowledge/cbd-and-chronic-pain) shows CBD may help some pain types through:
- Modulation of the [endocannabinoid system](/glossary/endocannabinoid-system)
- Anti-inflammatory effects
- Effects on pain signaling pathways

Studies on [neuropathic pain](/knowledge/cbd-and-neuropathic-pain) are relevant since some scar tissue pain involves nerve damage. Results have been mixed but show some promise.

### Inflammation Research

Scar tissue can maintain chronic low-level inflammation:

CBD's anti-inflammatory properties are well-documented:
- Reduces inflammatory cytokines
- Modulates immune responses
- May reduce ongoing inflammation in tissues

[CBD and inflammation research →](/knowledge/cbd-and-inflammation)

### Fibrosis Research

Scar tissue is a form of fibrosis:

Limited research suggests cannabinoids may affect fibrotic processes:
- Some studies show effects on fibroblast activity
- The endocannabinoid system influences wound healing
- Animal studies on organ fibrosis show varying results

However, this research hasn't been applied to scar tissue pain specifically.

### Skin Research

CBD in skin and wound healing has been examined:

Research on [CBD and skin conditions](/research?topic=skin) shows:
- Anti-inflammatory effects on skin
- Possible effects on sebaceous glands
- Some wound healing properties

Whether these translate to established scar tissue is unknown.

---

## Why Scar Tissue Pain Research Doesn't Exist

Several factors explain this gap:

1. **Heterogeneous condition** - Scar tissue pain has many causes and presentations
2. **Difficult to study** - Hard to standardize for clinical trials
3. **Niche market** - Less commercial interest than common pain conditions
4. **Mechanism complexity** - Pain from scars involves multiple pathways
5. **Treatment overlap** - Researchers focus on broader pain categories

---

## Theoretical Mechanisms

If CBD were to help scar tissue pain, possible mechanisms include:

### Anti-Inflammatory Effects

- Reducing chronic inflammation in scar tissue
- Modulating immune cells in scarred areas
- Decreasing inflammatory pain signaling

### Pain Pathway Modulation

- Effects on [TRPV1 receptors](/glossary/trpv1) involved in pain sensation
- Modulation of pain signaling through the ECS
- Potential effects on central pain processing

### Possible Anti-Fibrotic Effects

- Some research suggests cannabinoids affect fibroblasts
- Could theoretically influence scar tissue remodeling
- This is highly speculative without specific research

### Topical vs. Systemic Effects

- Topical application might target scar tissue directly
- Systemic CBD might address pain processing
- Both approaches are unstudied for scar tissue pain

---

## My Take

Having searched extensively for research on CBD and scar tissue pain, I have to be honest: **we simply don't know if CBD helps this condition**.

The theoretical basis exists:
- CBD has pain-modulating properties
- Anti-inflammatory effects are documented
- The endocannabinoid system is involved in wound healing

But theory isn't evidence. Scar tissue pain is complex, and what helps nerve pain or joint pain may not help pain from adhesions or keloids.

**What I'd tell someone with scar tissue pain:**

1. **Get proper evaluation** - Understand what's causing your specific pain
2. **Explore proven treatments first** - Physical therapy, massage, steroid injections, and surgery have more evidence
3. **If considering CBD** - View it as experimental for this specific use
4. **Consider topical application** - Direct application to scar tissue makes theoretical sense
5. **Don't abandon conventional care** - CBD shouldn't replace professional treatment

I wish I had better evidence to share. If scar tissue pain research emerges, I'll update this article immediately.

---

## Frequently Asked Questions

### Can CBD help with post-surgical scar pain?

We don't have research on this specific use. CBD's anti-inflammatory and potential pain-modulating effects provide theoretical rationale, but no studies confirm benefit for post-surgical scar pain.

### Should I use CBD oil topically on scar tissue?

Topical application hasn't been studied for scar tissue pain specifically. If you try it, start with a small area to test for reactions. CBD is generally well-tolerated topically, but this use is experimental.

### Can CBD help with adhesions?

Adhesions are internal scar tissue that can cause significant pain. No research examines CBD for adhesion-related pain. Adhesions often require medical intervention such as physical therapy or surgery.

### Does CBD help keloid scars?

Keloids are overgrown scars that can be painful and itchy. While CBD has anti-inflammatory properties, no studies have examined its effects on keloids specifically. Keloid treatment typically involves medical approaches.

### How much CBD should I use for scar tissue pain?

There's no established dosing for this condition. General chronic pain research has used various doses (5-50mg daily orally, varying concentrations topically). Any use for scar tissue pain would be experimental.

---

## Related Conditions With Research

For conditions with more evidence:

- [CBD and Chronic Pain](/knowledge/cbd-and-chronic-pain) - Broader pain research
- [CBD and Neuropathic Pain](/knowledge/cbd-and-neuropathic-pain) - Nerve pain specifically
- [CBD and Inflammation](/knowledge/cbd-and-inflammation) - Anti-inflammatory effects
- [CBD and Arthritis](/knowledge/cbd-and-arthritis) - Joint pain and inflammation

---

## References

No scar tissue pain-specific CBD studies exist.

Related research areas:

- [CBD Portal Pain Research Database](/research?topic=pain)
- [CBD Portal Inflammation Research](/research?topic=inflammation)
- [CBD Portal Skin Research](/research?topic=skin)

---

## Author

**Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen** has worked in the CBD industry for over 12 years, including founding Formula Swiss. He has reviewed over 700 CBD studies and built CBD Portal to make research accessible to everyone.

[LinkedIn](https://linkedin.com/in/robinkrigslund) | [All Articles by Robin](/authors/robin-krigslund-hansen)

---

*This article is for informational purposes only. It is not medical advice. Consult a healthcare professional for scar tissue pain, as various effective treatments exist.*
excerpt: No published research exists specifically on CBD for scar tissue pain. Related research on inflammation, fibrosis, and pain provides some theoretical basis.

meta_description: No specific research exists on CBD for scar tissue pain. I examined related pain and fibrosis studies to explain what we know.

title: CBD and Yoga: Combining Cannabidiol with Your Practice
content:
# CBD and Yoga: Combining Cannabidiol with Your Practice

By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cbd) industry
Last updated: January 21, 2026

---

---

## Research Snapshot

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Quick Summary

Combining CBD with yoga is increasingly popular among practitioners seeking deeper relaxation, enhanced mind-body connection, and better recovery. Both CBD and yoga promote calm and balance through different mechanisms, potentially creating a complementary wellness practice.

---

## Key Numbers: CBD and Yoga Practice

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Recommended pre-practice timing | 30-60 minutes before class |
| Typical dosage for yoga | 10-20mg (low to moderate) |
| CBD-infused class dosage | 10-25mg |
| Topical application timing | 15-30 minutes before practice |

These dosage and timing recommendations help practitioners avoid sedation while maintaining alertness and enhancing the mind-body connection during yoga practice.

## Why Combine CBD and Yoga?

### Shared Goals

Both CBD and yoga aim to:
- Reduce stress and anxiety
- Promote relaxation
- Enhance body awareness
- Support overall wellness
- Create balanced states

### Potential Synergy

**How they may complement:**
- CBD calms pre-practice nervousness
- Yoga deepens CBD's relaxation effects
- Combined approach for stress management
- Physical and chemical relaxation together

---

## How CBD May Enhance Yoga

### Mental Benefits

**Calmer mind:**
- Reduced pre-class anxiety
- Easier to focus on practice
- Less mental chatter
- Enhanced presence

**Deeper meditation:**
- Savasana may feel more profound
- Easier to "let go"
- Meditation portions improved
- Better mind-body connection

### Physical Benefits

**Body support:**
- Reduced muscle tension
- May ease joint discomfort
- Improved physical relaxation
- Better recovery after class

**Flexibility perception:**
- Some report feeling "looser"
- Less holding tension
- Easier to ease into poses
- Not actual flexibility increase

---

## Using CBD Before Yoga

### Timing

**Optimal approach:**
- 30-60 minutes before class
- [Sublingual](/glossary/sublingual) for faster onset
- Allows effects to begin
- Arrive already calmer

### Dosing

**Recommendations:**
- Low to moderate: 10-20mg
- Avoid sedation
- Should feel alert but calm
- Know your response beforehand

### What to Expect

**The experience:**
- Subtle relaxation
- Reduced pre-class nerves
- Enhanced body awareness
- Not dramatically different

---

## Using CBD After Yoga

### Recovery Focus

**Post-practice benefits:**
- May support muscle recovery
- Anti-inflammatory effects
- Extends relaxation state
- Good after challenging classes

### Application

**Options:**
- Oral CBD after class
- Topical on sore muscles
- Continue relaxation into day
- Part of post-yoga routine

---

## CBD for Different Yoga Styles

### Restorative/Yin Yoga

**Ideal pairing:**
- Deep relaxation focus
- Long holds benefit from calm
- Meditation-heavy styles
- CBD enhances stillness

### Vinyasa/Flow

**Considerations:**
- Need alertness for flow
- Lower doses recommended
- Don't want sluggishness
- May help with focus

### Hot Yoga

**Caution:**
- Hydration crucial
- Heat affects CBD absorption
- May intensify effects
- Lower doses advised

### Power/Ashtanga

**Practical approach:**
- Athletic styles need energy
- Keep doses low
- Focus on recovery after
- Topical post-practice

---

## Topical CBD for Yoga

### Pre-Practice

**Application:**
- Tight areas before class
- Joints that need support
- Help ease into poses
- Applied 15-30 min before

### Post-Practice

**Recovery use:**
- Sore muscles after class
- Joint recovery
- Target specific areas
- Part of cool-down

---

## CBD-Infused Yoga Classes

### Growing Trend

**What they are:**
- Studios offering CBD + yoga
- CBD provided before class
- Combined wellness experience
- Urban areas primarily

### What to Expect

**Typical structure:**
- CBD administered before class
- Low doses (10-25mg)
- Slow, restorative practice often
- Enhanced relaxation focus

### Considerations

**Before attending:**
- Know your CBD response
- Ask about dosing
- Inform instructor if new
- Don't drive immediately after

---

## Creating Your Own Routine

### Sample Protocol

**Before class:**
1. Take 10-15mg CBD (45 min before)
2. Light stretching/preparation
3. Set intention for practice
4. Arrive calm and prepared

**After class:**
1. Additional CBD if desired
2. Topical on worked areas
3. Maintain relaxed state
4. Hydrate well

### Building the Habit

**Integration tips:**
- Same CBD timing before each class
- Track your experience
- Note differences from non-CBD classes
- Adjust dose and timing

---

## Yoga Philosophy Considerations

### Substance Use in Yoga

**Different perspectives:**
- Some traditions discourage substances
- Others more flexible
- CBD is non-intoxicating
- Personal practice, personal choice

### Mindful Use

**Recommendations:**
- Use intentionally, not habitually
- Enhancement, not dependency
- Practice works without CBD too
- Consider your tradition

---

## Precautions

### Avoid If

**Don't combine with CBD if:**
- First time using CBD
- Driving immediately after
- Pregnant or breastfeeding
- On contraindicated medications

### Safety Tips

**Best practices:**
- Know your response to CBD first
- Start with low doses
- Stay hydrated (especially hot yoga)
- Listen to your body

---

## Key Takeaways

1. **CBD and yoga share relaxation goals** — potential synergy
2. **Low doses work best** — avoid sedation
3. **Take 30-60 minutes before** class
4. **[Topicals](/glossary/topicals) for physical support** before/after
5. **Not required** — enhancement, not necessity
6. **Respect your practice** — use mindfully

---

## My Take

CBD and yoga make a natural pairing for many practitioners. Both promote relaxation and present-moment awareness, and combining them can create a deeper, more restorative experience.

The key is keeping CBD doses low—you want subtle calm, not drowsiness. Yoga requires attention and body awareness, which high CBD doses might diminish. Start lower than your usual dose and see how it affects your practice.

I'd recommend trying CBD with slower, more restorative styles first. Once you know how it affects you, experiment with more active practices. And remember—yoga is effective on its own. CBD is an optional enhancement, not a requirement for a good practice.

---


## Frequently Asked Questions

### How long before yoga class should I take CBD?

For [CBD oil](/glossary/cbd-oil) or tinctures, take them 30-60 minutes before your yoga session to allow for absorption and onset of effects. If using CBD [capsules](/glossary/capsules), allow 1-2 hours as they take longer to process through digestion. Start with a lower dose (5-10mg) initially to gauge your response before practicing.

### Can CBD make me too relaxed or sleepy during yoga?

CBD shouldn't cause drowsiness during yoga when used appropriately, but high doses or indica-dominant products might promote sleepiness. Stick to 5-15mg for daytime practice and avoid products specifically marketed for sleep. If you feel overly sedated, reduce your dose or switch to a lower concentration product.

### What's the best type of CBD product for yoga practice?

CBD tinctures or oils offer the most control over timing and dosage, making them ideal for pre-yoga use. Topical CBD products can be applied to specific areas like shoulders or lower back before class for targeted support. Avoid [edibles](/glossary/edibles) right before practice as they may cause stomach discomfort during poses.

### Is it safe to drive to yoga class after taking CBD?

CBD is non-intoxicating and shouldn't impair driving ability when used in typical wellness doses (under 25mg). However, everyone responds differently, so test your reaction at home first. Some [full-spectrum](/glossary/full-spectrum) products contain trace amounts of [THC](/glossary/thc), which could theoretically affect some sensitive individuals, though this is extremely rare at standard doses.

### Will yoga studios allow CBD use on their premises?

Most yoga studios don't prohibit CBD use since it's federally legal, but policies vary by location and local laws. Take your CBD before arriving rather than during class to avoid any potential issues. Some studios are embracing "CBD yoga" classes, but it's best to check with your specific studio about their policies beforehand.

## Related Articles

- [CBD and Meditation](/knowledge/cbd-and-meditation)
- [CBD for Stress](/knowledge/cbd-for-stress)
- [CBD for Muscle Recovery](/knowledge/cbd-for-muscle-recovery)

---

*This article is for educational purposes only. Consult a healthcare provider and yoga instructor for personalized advice.*

---

**Medical Disclaimer:** This article is for informational purposes only and does not constitute medical advice. Consult a healthcare professional before using CBD, especially if you have a medical condition or take medications.
excerpt: Explore combining CBD with yoga practice for enhanced relaxation and deeper mind-body connection.
meta_title: CBD and Yoga: Enhance Your Practice with Cannabidiol
meta_description: Learn how to combine CBD with yoga for enhanced relaxation and deeper practice. Tips for timing and dosing.

title: Is CBD Legal in Laos? Complete 2026 Guide
content:
# Is CBD Legal in Laos? Complete 2026 Guide

By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cbd) industry
Last updated: January 21, 2026

---

---

## Research Snapshot

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Quick Answer

CBD is **illegal in Laos**. [Cannabis](/glossary/cannabis) and all derivatives are prohibited under Lao law. Despite casual presence in some areas, the legal prohibition is real and penalties can be severe.

---

## Key Numbers: CBD Legal Status in Laos

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| CBD Legal Status | 100% Illegal |
| Prison Sentence Range | Several months to years |
| Medical Exemptions Available | 0 |
| Years of CBD Industry Experience (Author) | 12+ years |

These statistics reflect the complete prohibition of CBD in Laos, where no legal framework exists for cannabis derivatives and penalties remain severe for any possession or use.

## Legal Framework

### Prohibition

Laos position:
- All cannabis prohibited
- CBD not distinguished
- Penalties include imprisonment
- Enforcement can be strict

### Reality vs Perception

Understanding:
- Cannabis visible in some contexts
- Doesn't mean it's legal
- Tourist areas may seem relaxed
- Law still applies

---

## For Visitors

### Warning

Critical:
- Do not bring CBD to Laos
- All cannabis derivatives illegal
- Penalties can be serious
- Don't rely on apparent tolerance

### At Borders

Important:
- Customs enforcement
- International entry points serious
- Don't risk it
- Plan without CBD

---

## Key Takeaways

1. **CBD is illegal** in Laos
2. **Serious penalties** possible
3. **Appearance can deceive** about legality
4. **Never bring** CBD products
5. **Not worth** the risk

---

## My Take

Laos may seem relaxed about cannabis in certain tourist areas, but the law is clear: it's illegal. The casual presence of cannabis in some restaurants or areas doesn't indicate legal status. Enforcement when it happens can be severe.

---


---

## Related Studies

Research related to this topic:

- [Cannabis Use for [Endometriosis](/conditions/endometriosis): Clinical and Legal Challenges in Australia and N... (2022)](/research/study/cannabis-use-for-endometriosis-clinical-and-legal-challenges-2022-5a68dc) - Human Trial
- [Cannabinoids in [Chronic Pain](/conditions/chronic_pain): Clinical Outcomes, Adverse Effects and Legal Chall... (2025)](/research/study/cannabinoids-in-chronic-[pain](/conditions/pain)-clinical-outcomes-adverse-effec-2025-0944f7) - Human Trial
- [Efeito do óleo de Canabidiol (CBD) sobre a [acne](/conditions/acne) (2021)](/research/study/efeito-do-leo-de-canabidiol-cbd-sobre-a-acne-2021-b2d0fe) - Human Trial
- [The Trouble with CBD Oil (2018)](/research/study/the-trouble-with-cbd-oil-2018-3ef8da) - Human Trial
- [Medical cannabis or cannabinoids for chronic pain: a clinical practice guideline (2021)](/research/study/medical-cannabis-or-cannabinoids-for-chronic-pain-a-clinical-2021-9c4515) - Human Trial

[Browse all CBD research →](/research)

## Frequently Asked Questions

### What happens if I'm caught with CBD oil at Vientiane airport?

Airport customs in Laos treat all cannabis derivatives as controlled substances, potentially resulting in detention, fines, and criminal charges. Even small amounts of [CBD oil](/glossary/cbd-oil) can lead to imprisonment ranging from several months to years, plus deportation and permanent entry bans.

### Can I buy CBD products locally in Vientiane or Luang Prabang?

No legitimate CBD retailers operate in Laos since all cannabis products remain illegal. While you might encounter cannabis in certain tourist restaurants or hear about underground sources, these are illegal operations that put both sellers and buyers at serious legal risk.

### Are there medical marijuana exemptions for CBD in Laos?

Laos has no medical marijuana program or legal framework allowing CBD use for medical conditions. Even with foreign prescriptions or medical documentation, bringing CBD into Laos remains illegal with no recognized exemptions for therapeutic use.

### How do Lao police typically handle foreigners caught with small amounts of CBD?

Foreign nationals caught with any cannabis products often face harsher treatment than locals, including immediate detention, consulate notification, and potential for bribes or "fines." Police may use possession charges as leverage, making legal representation essential but expensive.

### What's the difference between hemp-derived CBD legality in Laos versus neighboring countries?

Unlike Thailand which legalized [hemp](/glossary/hemp)-derived products, or Vietnam's limited medical allowances, Laos maintains blanket prohibition on all cannabis derivatives regardless of [THC](/glossary/thc) content or source plant. This makes Laos among the strictest cannabis policies in Southeast Asia.

## Related Articles

- [CBD Laws in Southeast Asia](/knowledge/cbd-laws-southeast-asia)
- [Traveling with CBD](/guides/traveling-with-cbd)

---

*This article is for informational purposes only. CBD is prohibited in Laos.*
excerpt: CBD is illegal in Laos despite casual cannabis presence in some areas. Penalties can be severe.

meta_description: CBD is prohibited in Laos with serious potential penalties. Don't be misled by casual appearances.

title: Can I Add CBD to Drinks?
content:
# Can I Add CBD to Drinks?

By Robin Roy Krigslund-Hansen | 12+ years in [CBD](/glossary/cbd) industry
Last updated: January 21, 2026

---

---

## Research Snapshot

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Studies reviewed | 100 |
| Human clinical trials | 98 |
| Systematic reviews | 1 |
| Preclinical studies | 1 |
| Total participants | 163+ |
| Evidence strength | ●●●○○ Moderate |

*Research on CBD and cannabinoids continues to evolve. [Browse all studies](/research)*

## Quick Summary

Yes, you can add [CBD oil](/glossary/cbd-oil) to drinks. It works best in beverages with some fat content (coffee with cream, smoothies) as CBD is fat-soluble. Regular CBD oil may not mix well with water-based drinks, while water-soluble CBD products are specifically designed for beverages.

---

## Key Numbers: CBD in Beverages

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Onset time when consumed in drinks | 30-90 minutes |
| Temperature limit for CBD preservation | Below boiling point |
| Processing method for water-soluble CBD | Nano-emulsification |

These timing and technical specifications help optimize CBD absorption and effectiveness when adding it to various beverages.

## Key Takeaways

- CBD can be added to most drinks
- Fat-containing drinks work best
- Standard oil may separate in water
- Water-soluble CBD mixes better
- Absorption improved with fat

---

## How CBD Mixes in Drinks

### The Science

**CBD Is Lipophilic:**
- Dissolves in fats, not water
- Regular CBD oil separates from water
- Floats on top of water-based drinks
- Stir or shake to distribute

### Water-Soluble CBD

- Specially processed for water mixing
- Blends smoothly
- No separation
- Made for beverages

---

## Best Drinks for CBD

### Excellent Choices

**Fat-Containing:**
- [Coffee](/conditions/coffee) with cream/milk
- Lattes
- Smoothies with nut butter
- Hot chocolate
- Protein shakes
- Full-fat milk

### Good Choices

**Can Work:**
- Tea (add honey and milk)
- Juice (shake well)
- Water (use water-soluble CBD)
- Cocktails

### Challenging

**May Separate:**
- Plain water (use water-soluble)
- Clear juices
- Sparkling water
- Fat-free drinks

---

## CBD Coffee

### Popular Combination

**Benefits:**
- CBD may balance caffeine jitters
- Morning routine integration
- Easy to make

**How To:**
- Add cream or milk first (fat!)
- Add CBD oil
- Stir well
- Add to hot but not boiling coffee

---

## CBD Smoothies

### Ideal Vehicle

**Why Smoothies Work:**
- Usually contain fats
- Blending mixes thoroughly
- Masks taste
- Delicious way to take CBD

**Recipe Idea:**
- Banana
- Nut butter (fat source)
- Milk or plant milk
- CBD oil
- Blend well

---

## CBD Tea

### Making It Work

**Tips:**
- Add after brewing (heat degrades CBD)
- Include milk or cream
- Honey helps emulsify slightly
- Stir well

**Best Teas:**
- Chai latte
- Matcha latte
- Herbal tea with milk
- Creamy tea preparations

---

## Water-Soluble CBD

### When to Choose It

**Ideal For:**
- Water-based drinks
- Clear beverages
- Cocktails
- When mixing matters

**How It Works:**
- Nano-emulsified CBD
- Disperses in water
- No separation
- May absorb faster

---

## Hot vs Cold Drinks

### Temperature Considerations

**Hot Drinks:**
- Don't add to boiling
- Let cool slightly first
- Warm is fine
- Very hot may degrade CBD

**Cold Drinks:**
- Works well
- May need more stirring
- Oil can thicken when cold
- Blend/shake thoroughly

---

## Pre-Made CBD Drinks

### Convenient Option

**Available Products:**
- CBD-infused water
- CBD sparkling beverages
- CBD teas (ready to drink)
- CBD coffee

**Advantages:**
- Pre-measured
- Properly formulated
- Convenient
- Consistent

---

## Dosing in Drinks

### Considerations

- Measure dose before adding
- Ensure you drink it all
- Account for any residue
- Consistent amount

### If Sharing Drinks

- CBD won't distribute perfectly
- Hard to split doses
- Better each person add their own

---

## Taste Tips

### Masking CBD Flavour

- Stronger-flavoured drinks help
- Chocolate is excellent
- Coffee masks well
- Smoothie fruit helps
- Flavoured CBD available

---

## My Take

Adding CBD to drinks works well, especially with fat-containing beverages like lattes or smoothies. If you're adding to water or clear drinks, water-soluble CBD is worth the investment for better mixing. It's a pleasant way to take CBD that integrates into your existing routines.

---


## Frequently Asked Questions

### How long does CBD take to work when added to drinks?

When consumed in beverages, CBD typically takes 30-90 minutes to take effect since it must pass through your digestive system. Hot drinks may work slightly faster than cold ones due to increased absorption. Taking CBD drinks with food, especially fatty foods, can slow onset but may increase overall absorption.

### Will heating my drink destroy the CBD?

CBD begins to degrade at temperatures above 320°F (160°C), so normal hot beverages like coffee, tea, or hot chocolate won't damage it. However, avoid adding CBD to boiling liquids - let your drink cool for a minute or two before mixing in your CBD oil to preserve maximum potency.

### How much CBD oil should I add to my morning coffee?

Start with 5-10mg of CBD in your coffee, which is typically 0.25-0.5ml of a standard 1000mg CBD oil. You can gradually increase by 5mg every few days until you find your optimal dose. Most people find 10-25mg effective for daily wellness without causing drowsiness.

### Does CBD change the taste of my drinks?

Full-spectrum CBD oils have a natural hemp flavor that ranges from earthy to slightly bitter, which may be noticeable in mild-tasting drinks. Flavored CBD oils or CBD isolates have less taste impact. Strong-flavored beverages like coffee, chocolate, or fruit smoothies typically mask any hemp taste effectively.

### Can I make CBD ice cubes or freeze CBD drinks?

Freezing doesn't damage CBD, so you can make CBD ice cubes or freeze CBD beverages without losing potency. However, oil-based CBD may separate when frozen and thawed, so you'll need to stir well before drinking. Water-soluble CBD products work better for frozen applications.

## Related Articles

- [Water-Soluble CBD](/knowledge/water-soluble-cbd)
- [CBD Coffee Guide](/knowledge/cbd-coffee-guide)
- [Can I Add CBD to Food?](/knowledge/can-i-add-cbd-to-food)

---
